title: Firefox causes entire screen to fade to black for 1 second
content:
Hi, I'm trying to find out what's causing this behavior. My firefox sometimes, specifically when opening a second tab (doesn't happen on a third, fourth, fifth, etc. tab) and pressing F (like starting to type Facebook), makes my entire screen to fade to black for 1 second, and then comes back. If I do type facebook, it shows "acebook", ignoring the F entirely. It doesn't seem like a crash, it seems a lot like a functionality of sorts that's acting up, because it doesn't go black just like that, it fades. And it always takes the same amount of time with that fade.

What's worse, it doesn't always happen. If it happens once I can replicate it and keep doing it, but as I use the browser and it stops doing it, I can't do it again. Until, well, it does.

This is the weirdest thing. How does firefox control my entire screen like that? What's it doing? What instruction on my keyboard is F sending to firefox?

I haven't found anything like this happening to anyone online.

Any help please?

title: Activity Monitor vs. about:performance Understanding Memory Discrepancy
content:
Hello. Using Firefox for latest OSX (ff 86.0 but I really don't think version is going to matter for this question).

Can someone help me understand how to interpret memory consumption results that Firefox provides vs. what is shown in Activity Monitor? FF shows tabs consuming in the 10's of megs, Activity Monitor shows in the ~500 meg range. I thought maybe FF was closer to the truth because it was factoring in shared memory across tabs (and the 'true' memory impact per tab was less) but I can't figure out how to connect these things together. Any help appreciated!

Huge fan of Firefox and Mozilla!

George
creator: r3cgm

title: Firefox 86 default printer (print_printer) changed any time you use a secondary printer, causing print preview to fail
content:
First the hardware and software: Ubuntu Linux 20.10, Firefox 86, HP OfficeJet 8600, Dymo LabelWriter 330

After successfully printing to a secondary printer (the Dymo using an address label paper size), the new "print preview" hangs. It appears that the print_printer setting in about:config gets changed to the Dymo instead of my default printer (the HP). The only way that I have found to correct this problem is to go into about:config EVERY time I print something to the Dymo from Firefox, then delete the stored value. I never had this problem until the latest version of Firefox. It would sure be nice to be able to either leave the setting going to my default printer, or at a minimum, for Firefox to go back to the traditional print dialog where the desired printer could be selected instead of unsuccessfully trying to render the page for the wrong printer.

title: Firefox (on normal mode) randomly freezes and shuts down after win update. Tried so many solutions already!
content:
Good day.

Yesterday I had to install the latest windows 10 updates and while this went fine on my laptop, on my desktop it messed up firefox (somehow). Within 10 minutes the darn thing freezes up and crashes, something that does not happen in safe mode. I suspected that it was my nvidia 3080 card as I read it is having some problems, but reinstalling drivers/everything did nothing.

What solutions I have tried: Proper reinstall of firefox. I wiped all the files of my pc, registry, everything. Scoured as much as I could find. Installed, got my passwords off my laptop, seemed promising and ...nop, problem still here.

Disabled hardware acceleration. Didn't help at all. Disabled all add-ons when starting firefox normally. Still same problem. Wiped the cache again, kept addons and acceleration disabled, disabled firefox updater (and some system check-thing as some recommended) and still the problem is there.

I outright started to fully wipe and reinstall stuff like my nvidia drivers with specialized software, but that also didn't help. What on earth could it be? Is windows somehow messed up? But then why does it work in safe mode and all other browsers work fine? It's just firefox :(

title: Web pages slow to load
content: I asked this question several months ago. The issue started with FF 79 and we are now on FF 86. I have a bit more information now, but not much. If I start FF, every web page that I go to pauses for ~8 seconds, and then begins to load. After about 2-3 days of this happening, FF starts working properly and loads web pages instantly instead of just sitting there doing nothing for the 8 seconds. FF will then work properly until I have to quit the program. When I restart, the same process happens again. This is frustrating as I have no idea why this would be happening. From my previous time asking this question, I was asked to disable my addons (didn't help), start FF in safe mode (did help), but nothing concrete came out of the discussion. I'm hoping someone else has had this problem in the meantime and has figured out what could be causing this problem.

title: Recently Closed Windows Restore All
content:
When I open recently closed windows one at a time (History -> Recently Closed Windows -> "window") there is no issue, but when I open multiple recently closed windows by selecting Restore All Windows (History -> Recently Closed Windows -> Restore All Windows) all the browser windows open but they are all blank and all my previous sessions are lost. This never happened until a few months ago and now it happens every time. What is the point of having the Restore All Windows option if it just deletes all previous sessions? Is this a bug? Robert

title: Disable redirect to https
content:
I know this has come up many times before, I've read the solutions like this: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1019210

But its old. There is also HSTS which Im not sure how that works and frankly, as a user I don't care.

We use internal websites on a company intranet domain. For example, a simple webpage to show the status of an application. I had to enable apache and made its config, so I know for a fact the site itself is not redirecting to https (other browsers aren't redirecting). Firefox insists on changing my address bar to https. When I use tcpdump or check the firewall, I dont even see port 80 traffic, firefox doesnt even try.

I tried the above, I also: - disabled addons (which I know dont redirect but to be sure) - erased the relevant history - deleted HSTS config file from my Mozilla profile - tried opening in a private window

The site above is an example, it happens with other sites too. Sometimes, it works for a while and then it stops. Sometimes, I find another site entry in the HSTS file, remove it and try again. Sometimes it works, sometimes it doesn't. I'm at a loss what to try next.

When I completely erase and start a new profile, without sync or addons, it might work but only for a short while. This isn't an option because literally, the only reason I still use firefox is because sync works reasonably well, across all devices, including most settings and addons.

I hope someone can help me fix this, I'd appreciate it!

title: I can't open any page or even preferences -- blank page shows up (Ubuntu)
content:
Since today I see a blank page when I open firefox. Everything was working ok before. I tried to purge firefox with all data and install again but the problem persists. I also tried to use firefox 85 and 86 from the website rather than from the apt-get package but this also didn't help. The same happens in safe-mode. I can't even access preferences, passwords, and other built-in pages. Please see the screenshot attached. I'm on Ubuntu 18.04.

When I close firefox it runs in the background and I have to kill the process manually.

Not having access to passwords is by far the most frustrating part in it.
